sense.def: when you owe money to someone
dictionaryExamples: They are in debt to the bank.
He got into debt after he lost his job.
The company is deep in debt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The consequence is that I'm in debt. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: when someone performs or presents something to the public for the first time
dictionaryExamples: She made her debut as a pianist in 1975.
This is the band's debut album.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Pavarotti's grand debut took place in the Royal Theatre of Reggio Emilia. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: a period of ten years, especially a period such as 1860 to 1869, or 2000 to 2009
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a question debated over the last decade whether television entertains and also educates. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: Decaffeinated tea or coffee is made by removing the caffeine.
dictionaryExamples: Could I have a decaffeinated coffee, please?

sense.def: to become gradually damaged or to cause something to become gradually damaged
dictionaryExamples: Sugar makes your teeth decay.
Pollution has decayed the surface of the stonework on the front of the cathedral.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The historic buildings are starting to decay. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: when something decays
dictionaryExamples: Many of the buildings had fallen into decay.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, by having tourism, the authorities of the country, such as the government, will be obliged to rest[ore] any monuments which have fallen into decay. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: dead
dictionaryExamples: the deceased man's belongings
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A picture of a deceased family member brings back lots of memor[ies]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: someone who has died
dictionaryExamples: There will be no service, at the deceased’s request.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The deceased was a 19-year-old girl who had run away from home some months ago. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to make someone believe something that is not true
dictionaryExamples: The company deceived customers by selling old computers as new ones.
The sound of the door closing deceived me into thinking they had gone out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So if you don't want to feel deceived or offended, think twice before you decide to go shopping. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the twelfth and last month of the year
dictionaryExamples: the 23rd of December/December 23(rd)
Their baby was born last December.
Jonathan  finishes his course next December.
My parents got married in/during December.
It was one of the coldest Decembers ever.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can see it on December 15th. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: of a satisfactory quality or level
dictionaryExamples: He earns a decent salary.
I haven't had a decent cup of coffee since I've been here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it's a decent place for us to stay for a night. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: honest and morally good
dictionaryExamples: Decent people have had their lives ruined by his behavior.
She should do the decent thing and apologize.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, it had such [a] bad reputation that nobody "decent" went there any longer. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: when you make someone believe something that is not true
dictionaryExamples: He was found guilty of obtaining money by deception.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, his deception means that he betrayed his own nation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If something is deceptive, it makes you believe something that is not true.
dictionaryExamples: Appearances can be deceptive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One should also remember another common, albeit wise phrase: appearances can be deceptive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to choose something after thinking about several possibilities
dictionaryExamples: They have to decide by next Friday.
I don't care which one we have - you decide.
In the end, we decided to go to the theater.
She decided (that) she would retire to Florida.
I can't decide what to do.
He can't decide whether to buy it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have decided to paint my room orange. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: to cause something to have a particular result
dictionaryExamples: This match will decide the tournament.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At any rate, science will decide whether it is better to live longer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: something important that helps to make the final decision
dictionaryExamples: Cost was the deciding factor in choosing this builder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally, I think the quality of teachers, school reputation and facilities should be the deciding factor[s] for parents [i]n which schools their children should be educated in. International English Language Testing System; C2; Malay

sense.def: a choice that you make about something after thinking about several possibilities
dictionaryExamples: She had to make some very difficult decisions.
The company will reach/come to/make a decision shortly.
Let me have a/your decision by next week.
It was his decision to leave.
We need to take a lot of factors into account in our decision-making.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tell me your decision soon. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: able to make decisions quickly and confidently, or showing this quality
dictionaryExamples: You need to be more decisive.
a decisive reply
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were attractive, handsome, brave and decisive men. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: strongly affecting how a situation will progress or end
dictionaryExamples: a decisive action/victory
DNA test results were decisive in proving his innocence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Recently, our Board of Executives has taken a decisive step: from now on, our clothes will also be available for purchase on the Internet! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: in a decisive way
dictionaryExamples: We need to act decisively.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Putting your foot down quickly and decisively before things really get out of hand seems sensible. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a set of cards that you use to play a game
dictionaryExamples: I brought a deck of cards so we can play on the train.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I forgot my Yu-gi-oh card deck at your house yesterday. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: the flat area of a ship  or boat that is not covered
dictionaryExamples: We sat on deck until it was dark.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I woke up and went on the deck, I saw the skipper who [was coming] back from the village in the small boat. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a statement, often one that is written and official
dictionaryExamples: a declaration of independence/war
a customs declaration
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  The Spanish government has not been an exception and has tried to control pollution. Apart from taking part in world conferences and joining K[yo]to's declaration, it has also take[n] some measures. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to officially tell someone the value of goods you have bought, or the amount of money you have earned, because you might have to pay tax
dictionaryExamples: Have you got anything to declare?

sense.def: to announce something publicly or officially
dictionaryExamples: They declared their support for the proposal.
The US declared waron Japan in 1941.
The country declared independence in 1952.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We should declare [the city center] a pedestrian zone. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to gradually become less or worse
dictionaryExamples: His interest in the project declined after his wife died.
The party's popularity has declined in the opinion polls.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It had slightly declined to about 88 per cent in 1992. International English Language Testing System; [no level]; Chinese

sense.def: to refuse politely
dictionaryExamples: I invited him to the meeting but he declined.
He declined my offer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We thank you for your offer of accommodation, but we decline it. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: when something becomes less in amount, importance, quality or strength
dictionaryExamples: industrial decline
Home cooking seems to be on the/in decline.
a sharp decline in sales
She seemed to be recovering and then she went into a decline.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For the 25-34 age group, a decline can be seen from 2006 to 2010. International English Language Testing System; [no level]; Chinese

sense.def: to add something to or change an object or place to make it attractive
dictionaryExamples: They decorated the hall with balloons and colorful flags.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The church always is decorated with beautiful flowers and other things. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: something that you put on something to make it look attractive or special, or the activity of putting things on something to make it look more attractive or special
dictionaryExamples: Christmas/party/table/cake decorations
He's written a book on home decoration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I worked at the festival, I helped out with the decorations. First Certificate in English; B2; Malay

sense.def: made to look attractive
dictionaryExamples: a decorative display of plants and flowers
a mirror in a decorative frame
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seems that the decorative role of clothes will have disappeared by the year  2050. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to become less, or to make something become less
dictionaryExamples: During the summer months, rainfall decreases.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The aim to satisfy different interests should not [allow] the quality [to] decrease. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a reduction
dictionaryExamples: There has been a steady decrease in the number of visitors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their yellow and black stripe has a mysterious beauty (which is the main reason for the huge decrease [in the] tiger population). First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: believing that something is very important and giving a lot of time and energy to it
dictionaryExamples: a dedicated teacher
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I myself am a totally dedicated sports fan and I believe that basketball is the greatest sport on this earth. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: designed to be used for a particular purpose
dictionaryExamples: The city has created hundreds of miles of dedicated bike lanes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart from the occasional dedicated traffic lane, busses suffer the same congestion as other motorized traffic. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: when you are willing to give a lot of time and energy to something because you believe it is very important
dictionaryExamples: She thanked the staff for their dedication and enthusiasm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sacrifice and self-denial are cornerstones, together with dedication and commitment to a good cause. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: to decide that something is true using the available information
dictionaryExamples: From the contents of his shopping basket, I deduced that he was single.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having considered this particular case, we may be able to deduce some of the qualities needed to be "successful." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when an amount or a part of something is taken away from a total, or the amount that is taken
dictionaryExamples: tax deductions
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the deduction of 5% administration expense and 10% entertainment cost, we contributed the remaining 85% of the surplus to the local hospital. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: when you decide something using the available information
dictionaryExamples: I worked out the facts by a process of deduction.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My deductions obviously went further, and I found relie[f in] thinking that neither [was] the story real nor [had] the lost diary even existed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to judge or consider something in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: The book was deemed appropriate for children ages six to eight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Were it not for the fact that we regard our job as adequately paid and providing sufficient free time, it could not be deemed a satisfactory one. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: having a long distance from the top to the bottom
dictionaryExamples: a deep river/sea/lake
The water's not deep here - look, I can touch the bottom.
The water's only ankle-/knee-/waist-deep, so we'll be able to get across the river easily.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That place is good for the famili[e]s too, because [the] water [is] not so deep.  (1980761; Skills for Life (Entry 1); ; A1 BREAKTHROUGH; 2007; Hungarian; ?)Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: A deep color is strong and dark.
dictionaryExamples: deep purple
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is tall and has got black hair and beautiful deep brown eyes. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: A deep feeling or experience is very strong.
dictionaryExamples: deep regret
Their son has been a deep disappointment to them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I fell into a deep depression, and took an extremely long time to recover. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: A deep sound is low.
dictionaryExamples: a wonderfully deep voice
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "I'm not Gary," a strange and deep voice answered, "I'm someone who wants to warn you that tomorrow, you are going to die." First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to fill your lungs with air
dictionaryExamples: Take a deep breath and relax.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But if you took a deep breath after reading the question, don't worry. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: having a distance of 6 inches/4 feet, etc. from the top to the bottom, or from the front to the back
dictionaryExamples: This end of the pool is eight feet deep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her father's friend, who is a professional scuba-diver, invited her to do her first immers[i]on on the reefs, 15 meter[s] deep. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when someone is sleeping in a way that makes it difficult to wake them up
dictionaryExamples: He fell into a deep sleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And then, he fell to a deep sleep, putting his sack next to him. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: serious and difficult to understand
dictionaryExamples: a deep and meaningful conversation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think we really need to go back to the classics to re[ce]ive something from the deep thinkers. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: throw sb in at the deep end

sense.def: to make someone start a new and difficult job or activity without helping them or preparing them for it
dictionaryExamples: My first job was to organize a huge conference - they really threw me in at the deep end!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sometimes we can be thrown in at the deep end and have qualms about making a decision. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: giving all of your attention to what you are thinking or talking about, and not noticing anything else
dictionaryExamples: I noticed that Ali and Ben were deep in conversation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was deep in thought, chewing on something brown and rectangular. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a long way into something from the top or outside
dictionaryExamples: They traveled deep into the forest.
He thrust his hands deep in(to) his pockets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I just fall deep into the story, into the writer's own world. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: If you know or feel something deep down, you are certain that it is true, or you feel it strongly although you do not admit it or show it.
dictionaryExamples: Deep down, I knew that I was right.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No, because I [feel] deep down that it's wrong to put animals behind bars. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: If a feeling or a problem goes deep, it is very strong or serious and has existed for a long time.
dictionaryExamples: Their commitment to this town runs deep.

sense.def: if someone's knowledge or understanding deepens, it increases.
dictionaryExamples: It certainly helped to deepen my understanding of the situation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although all the choices can contribute to deepen the knowledge of the students about languages, I think the most approp[r]iate would be the computer room. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to become worse or stronger, or to make something become worse or stronger
dictionaryExamples: The economic  crisis has deepened.

sense.def: extremely or strongly
dictionaryExamples: I'm deeply grateful to you.
He found her comments deeply irritating/annoying/offensive.
We don't want to get too deeply involved with these people.
After 20 years of marriage, they're still deeply in love.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was deeply impressed by the long-term cooperation between the zoo and the school. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: a large, wild animal that is sometimes hunted for food and has antlers (= long horns) if it is male
dictionaryExamples: a deer park
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be even nicer if there would be some wildlife in the par[k], like deer, walking free all over. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to win a victory over someone in a fight, war or competition
dictionaryExamples: Napoleon was defeated by the Duke of Wellington at the battle of Waterloo.
If we can defeat the Chicago Cubs, we'll be in the playoffs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I still remember when Marcelo became [number] 1 in 1998 after he defeated Andre Agassi in the final of the "fifth Grand Slam". First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to cause someone or something to fail
dictionaryExamples: The proposal to change the rules was narrowly defeated by 201 votes to 196.
I'm afraid anything that involves language learning has always defeated me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But it was useless, Tina's friends had defeated their plan, and her. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: when someone loses against someone else in a fight, war or competition
dictionaryExamples: After their defeat in battle, the soldiers surrendered.
Lat night the Yankees suffered their worst defeat ever.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The whole team will face serious problems, which may lead to big defeats. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when someone or something is made to fail
dictionaryExamples: The party suffered a stinging defeat in the last election.
The company was not ready to admit defeat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After long negotiations with the police, Linda admitted defeat and gave up. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a fault or problem with someone or something
dictionaryExamples: genetic defects
A mechanical defect caused the plane to crash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are also people that are overweight and it is not their own fault, because they suffer from genetic defects. International English Language Testing System; C1; German

sense.def: not in good condition or not working correctly
dictionaryExamples: I replaced the defective light.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The electric instal[l]ations are defective, some locks are broken, and the ceil[ing] leaks. Under these conditions, it's no wonder the library has no visitors. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to protect someone or something from being attacked, especially by fighting
dictionaryExamples: How can we defend our homeland if we don't have an army?
I'm going to karate lessons to learn how to defend myself.
White blood cells help defend the body against infection.

sense.def: to support someone or something that is being criticized
dictionaryExamples: The newspaper's editor defended his decision to publish the photos.
They are fighting to defend their beliefs/interests/rights.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do we know a lot of people nowadays who would be able to take the risk of being a prisoner for 10 or 20 years "just" to defend his beliefs? First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to try to show in a court that someone is not guilty of a crime
dictionaryExamples: He has hired two lawyers to defend him in court.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: An in[n]ocent man is arrested and the court ap[p]oints an attorney to defend him. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: someone on a sports team who tries to prevent the other team from scoring points, goals, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She's the best defender on the school's basketball team.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm mostly a defender, so scoring a goal for the first time gave me great pleasure! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: protection or support against attack, criticism or infection
dictionaryExamples: When Helen criticized me, Chris came/rushed to my defense.
She argued strongly in defense of her actions.
A good diet helps build the body's natural defenses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I exploded and made quite a speech in defense of reading. First Certificate in English; B2; Portugese

sense.def: the part of a sports team which tries to prevent the other team from scoring points
dictionaryExamples: I'm best playing defense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They said that I'm good at defense and they want that I be in reserve [for] the competition. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: the weapons and military forces that a country uses to protect itself against attack
dictionaryExamples: Spending on defense / Defense spending is increasing.
the defense industry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The majority of the government's expenditure went to other things apart from defense, education and health. International English Language Testing System; C1; English

sense.def: the person or people in a court who are accused of doing a crime, and their lawyer
dictionaryExamples: He was cross-examined by the defense.
a lawyer for the defense / a defense lawyer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He tried to explain that the counsel for the defen[s]e was one of the best old hands in the country but they did not [even] pretend to listen to him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: quick to protect yourself from being criticized
dictionaryExamples: He's very defensive about his weight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And because the traveler's own value system is challenged, he reacts in a defensive way. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a mistake or fault in something so that it is not good enough
dictionaryExamples: Parents are complaining of serious deficiencies in the education system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By studying the effects of rain and ways to handle the expected amount of water, one can plan the laying out of the new roads and correct the deficiencies in the present ones. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: when you do not have enough of something
dictionaryExamples: a vitamin   deficiency
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The baby was born with a chromosome deficiency and the specialists gave her a life expectancy of up to six months. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the amount by which the money that you spend is more than the money that you receive
dictionaryExamples: a budget   deficit
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, this could not be fulfilled by the government due to a huge budget deficit. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Mongolian

sense.def: to say exactly what something means, or what someone or something is like
dictionaryExamples: In the dictionary "reality" is defined as "the state of things as they are, rather than as they are imagined to be."
Your duties are clearly defined in the contract.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I guess you would have to define the word "fit" to answer that question. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: certain, fixed and not likely to change
dictionaryExamples: The date for the meeting - is that definite?
We need a definite answer by tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm really excited about your definite plans to come. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the grammatical name for the word "the" in English, or the words in other languages which have a similar use
dictionaryExamples: "The Loop," referring to the downtown area of Chicago, takes the definite article.

sense.def: without any doubt
dictionaryExamples: Have you definitely decided to go to Australia?
He definitely said he'd be here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So if I were you, I would definitely stay in the city. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to emphasize that there is no doubt that something is not true or will not happen, or to say "no"
dictionaryExamples: "Will the work be finished by June?" "Definitely not."
I don’t like that place and I’m definitely not going back there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's nice, but do you think that money is all that matters? Definitely not! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Bulgarian

sense.def: an explanation of the meaning of a word or phrase
dictionaryExamples: a dictionary definition
What is the definition of "mood"?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He tried to give a definition of friendship. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: how clear an image of something is in a photograph or on a screen
dictionaryExamples: They filmed using a high-definition camera.
There will be some loss of definition when you copy the video.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And, do not forget to appreciate the keyboard work from the legendary Tony Banks, and the spectacular guitar-playing from Mike Rutherford, all of them surrounded by three, huge, high-definition screens. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: certain, clear, and not likely to change
dictionaryExamples: a definitive answer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know many people who offer easy and definitive answers to every question. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to refuse to obey someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Some of these children openly defy their teachers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jack was the only one, or the most conspic[u]ous of all, to defy him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to be beyond what you could expect/find a category for/describe, etc.
dictionaryExamples: His success has defied expectations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The horror of th[ose] endless days, when the whole family was as if in suspension not knowing the final diagnosis, defies any description. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a unit for measuring temperature, shown by the symbol ° written after a number
dictionaryExamples: Water boils at 212 degrees Fahrenheit and 100 degrees Celsius/centigrade.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today it is very windy and too cold for bathing, just about 15 degrees. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: a title of achievement given for completing a course of study at a college or university
dictionaryExamples: "What is your degree in?" "Art History."
She's got a physics degree/a degree in physics from Princeton.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I completed my languages degree course at U.P.N University. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: an amount or level of something
dictionaryExamples: This job demands a high degree of skill.
There was some degree of truth in what she said.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is quite obvious that the modern society exploits natural resources to an extremely high degree.  First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a small level or amount of something
dictionaryExamples: There was some degree of truth in what she said.
The plan involves a degree of risk, but it is worth trying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, some degree of freedom is obviously necessary for [the] healthy development of a young individual. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to make something happen at a later time than originally planned or expected
dictionaryExamples: My plane was delayed an hour.
Could we delay the meeting a few days?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The bus was delayed and I decided to go on foot. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to cause someone or something to be slow or late
dictionaryExamples: I was delayed by traffic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The roads were crowded with a lot of traffic, so I got really delayed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: when you have to wait longer than expected for something to happen, or the time that you have to wait
dictionaryExamples: An accident caused long delays on the Interstate.
There has been a delay in the book's publication.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was terrible at Heathrow airport because my flight had a delay of over two hours. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: immediately
dictionaryExamples: This problem needs to be dealt with without delay.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Anyway, as I told you I wanted to go the resort, [once] I had booked a room, without delay. But on my way something happened. 
 First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: someone who is sent somewhere to represent a group of people, especially at a meeting
dictionaryExamples: The delegates were all given badges to wear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I participated at the opening of the new arts cente[r] as a delegate from my college. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to give someone else part of your work or some of your responsibilities
dictionaryExamples: He needs to learn to delegate or he'll never get everything done.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Let me call him Mr. X. His success is based on various qualities of modern leadership: he delegates as much responsibility as possible to subordinates and gives them all competence to carry out their tasks. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a group of people who have been chosen to represent a much larger group of people
dictionaryExamples: a delegation of Chinese officials
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, two weeks ago I had to go to Kiev to work as a translator with a delegation at the Ukrainian Central Bank. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to remove something, especially from a computer's memory
dictionaryExamples: All names have been deleted from the report.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't take notice of [the email] and deleted it again. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: done intentionally or planned
dictionaryExamples: a deliberate attack/insult/lie
This was a deliberate attempt to mislead us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm sure that his deliberate intention with this was to make us get closer. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: intentionally
dictionaryExamples: I'm sure he says these things deliberately to annoy me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many of them choose the bicycle deliberately, just to have at least a small amount of exercise before and after [the] hours they spend sitting at their desks. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: soft, light or gentle
dictionaryExamples: a delicate flavor
a delicate shade of pink
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She liked his delicate skin and his body's warmth. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: easy to damage or break
dictionaryExamples: delicate china

Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

Learner example: Now, you can [make a] deposit, have a record of your expenses, transfer funds from one account to another and even pay your credit card . 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

Learner example: I think this is the right job I was looking for because [it] is an opportunity to travel to [the] USA, which is my great desire. 
 First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: the things that will happen to someone in the future
dictionaryExamples: At last she feels in control of her own destiny.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was our parents' destiny, it is our destiny and is going to be our children's destiny, too. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a power that some people believe controls what will happen in the future
dictionaryExamples: Nick said it was destiny that we met.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If anybody ever asked me if I believed in destiny, I would hesitate. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to damage something so badly that it does not exist or cannot be used
dictionaryExamples: Most of the old part of the city was destroyed by bombs during the war.
The accident seemed to have completely/totally destroyed his confidence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The film described a terrible period of our history when a lot of people died and a lot of cities were destroyed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: when something is destroyed
dictionaryExamples: Many people are very concerned about the destruction of the rainforests.

weapons of mass destruction
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It can be a solution to avoid the concentration of pollution and consequently avoid the destruction of the buildings. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: separate and not joined or connected to another part, building, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Their new house has a detached garage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Its use in eye surgery began with a discovery, that it could help to repair a detached retina (of which existence Dr. Townes had never heard before). Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If someone is detached, they do not feel involved with someone or emotional about something.
dictionaryExamples: As a nurse, I see some very distressing things, but I try to stay detached.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Whereas Olivia was very much attracted by and interested in India's mysteries, Douglas had a much more detached view of India. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: giving a lot of information
dictionaryExamples: A witness gave a detailed description of the man.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We ran until we arrived at the police station where we gave a detailed description of that man and what had happened. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to discover or notice something, especially something that is difficult to see, hear, smell, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Some sounds cannot be detected by the human ear.
This special camera can detect bodies by their heat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The kind of contamination that can be detected and observed most easily is the air pollution. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: someone, especially a police officer, whose job is to discover information about a crime
dictionaryExamples: a private detective
detective stories
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know that you love detective stories. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: to become worse
dictionaryExamples: Her condition deteriorated rapidly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Otherwise, the situation will deteriorate more and more. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: when someone  continues trying to do something, although it is very difficult
dictionaryExamples: Andy Murray will need great determination and skill to win this match.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mandela tried to better the political situation of South Africa [-] he was strong enough to fight, he had determination. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to discover the facts or truth about something
dictionaryExamples: The doctors are still unable to determine what is wrong.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our feelings about the issue led our class to direct a survey among local residents in Fordham, in order to determine statistically how often the latter use Greendale Park. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: to decide what will happen
dictionaryExamples: Her test scores will determine which class she is assigned to.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It considers the reasons for these developments and highlights the trends which will determine the future of the job market. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: wanting to do something very much, and not letting anyone stop you
dictionaryExamples: I'm determined to get this piece of work finished today.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am determined to study computer engineering and pursue my education oversea[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: in grammar, a word which is used before a noun to show which particular example of the noun you are referring to
dictionaryExamples: In the phrases "my first boyfriend" and "that strange woman," the words "my" and "that" are determiners.

sense.def: something that stops people doing something because they are afraid of what will happen if they do
dictionaryExamples: They've installed a security camera as a deterrent to thieves.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also think that the assistance that the state provides acts as a deterrent in the sense that, in Britain for example, the income support or family credit can actually be higher than what some people can earn in a week of hard work: so, what is the point of working? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: harmful or damaging
dictionaryExamples: a detrimental effect
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This could have a detrimental effect on our city and, to be more specific, on tourism. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: very shocked and upset
dictionaryExamples: She was devastated when her husband died.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To begin with, everyone was devastated [at] how long we had to wait at the airport, as the flight to Dublin was late. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: making someone very shocked and upset
dictionaryExamples: Despite the devastating news, no one is giving up hope.

sense.def: to (cause something to) grow or change and become more advanced

sense.def: to make something new such as a product

sense.def: to start to happen or exist

sense.def: someone whose job is to create new products, especially computer products such as software
dictionaryExamples: We mostly use developers based in India.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, we may have the top website developers in China, but quite often the[ir] skills are [restrict]ed by poor IT infrastructures. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

dictionaryExamples: All the land was bought up by developers.

a development project in Pakistan
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are some machines which have helped in my development, and others which help to make my life easier. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the process of developing something new

sense.def: something new that happens and changes a situation

sense.def: an evil being, often represented in human form but with a tail and horns

sense.def: someone who behaves badly

sense.def: to design or invent something such as a system, plan, idea, piece of equipment, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She devised a plan to make money.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: On the other hand, I can't devise on the spot the job that would give you all the above-mentioned things, i.e., money and job satisfaction, and leave you plenty of free time simultaneously. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: a simple picture showing what something looks like or explaining something

sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: The diagram shows the system of production by which bricks are produced for the building industry. 
 International English Language Testing System; B1; Korean

dictionaryExamples: The play contained some very funny dialogue.

children with learning difficulties

First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

a digital watch

sense.def: when an employer officially makes someone leave their job
dictionaryExamples: a letter of dismissal
She accused her employers of unfair dismissal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another episod[e] of this sort is when Miss K. threatens to leave Darlington Hall because of the dismissal of the two Jewish maids. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: an illness or medical condition
dictionaryExamples: a mental/physical disorder
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We should react at an early stage of an eating disorder by watching ourselves, consulting a doctor and going to the fitness center. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: uncontrolled, bad behavior, especially by large groups of people
dictionaryExamples: crime and disorder
public/civil disorder
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although the transport facilities are good, the neighborhood has become increasingly dangerous, with numerous incidents of attacks and public disorder. International English Language Testing System; C1; Spanish

sense.def: when things are untidy or confused and not organized
dictionaryExamples: His finances are in complete disorder.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My home might, [to] an outsider, give the feeling of complete disorder, not to say craziness, but I can assure you that it was not true at all. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: not planned or organized well
dictionaryExamples: The whole conference was totally disorganized - nobody knew what they were supposed to be doing.

sense.def: not good at planning or organizing things
dictionaryExamples: He's impossible to work for - he's so disorganized.

sense.def: to take the place of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Many of these workers will be displaced by modern technology.

dictionaryExamples: Widespread flooding has led to the displacement of thousands of people.

sense.def: a collection of objects or pictures arranged for people to look at
dictionaryExamples: a display of children's paintings
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I decided to visit a museum which has a special display on Friday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: If something is on display, it is there for people to look at.
dictionaryExamples: Many old airplanes are on display at the museum.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were some new musical instruments on display. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: when something is shown electronically such as on a computer screen
dictionaryExamples: The display problems might be due to a shortage of disk space.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The phone has many facilities like games and color display. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: a performance or show for people to watch
dictionaryExamples: a fireworks display
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lastly, the fireworks display was wonderful and there were more than 5000 spectators who enjoyed themselves. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: when someone behaves in a way that shows they have a particular feeling or attitude
dictionaryExamples: The politicians shook hands in a display of unity for the media.

sense.def: to arrange something somewhere so that people can see it
dictionaryExamples: Family photographs were displayed on the wall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The problem [with] some museums is that the way in which the pieces of art are displayed is not right. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to show something electronically such as on a computer screen
dictionaryExamples: The text can be displayed and edited on screen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The timetable is hidden somewhere in a submenu which, I think, should be displayed on the main page. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to show how you feel by your expression or behavior
dictionaryExamples: He doesn’t display much emotion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The above feeling demonstrates about Okonkwo his constant anxiety to demonstrate - he and his son - constant manliness and [t]o not display any feeling of love, gentle[ne]ss and support even to his own children. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: intended to be used only once and then thrown away
dictionaryExamples: a disposable camera/razor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One drawback is the usage of disposable knives, forks and plates, which shouldn't be used nowadays. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the amount of money that you have available to spend after tax, rent and other basic things that you must pay
dictionaryExamples: Most of our customers have a large disposable income.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's true that people have more disposable income than ever, but surprisingly, people also have more debts. International English Language Testing System; C2; Thai

sense.def: when you get rid of something, especially by throwing it away
dictionaryExamples: waste disposal
the disposal of hazardous substances
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays waste disposal and environmental protection has become one of the most important questions of our life in a world with environmental catastrophes. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: available for you to use at any time
dictionaryExamples: We will have a car at our disposal for the whole trip.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But on Wednesday morning I'm at your disposal. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: the type of character someone has
dictionaryExamples: a cheerful/nervous disposition
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a really special girl with personal values and a really sweet disposition. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a disagreement, especially one that lasts a long time
dictionaryExamples: He and his neighbor have a long-running dispute over noise.

sense.def: to disagree with something someone says
dictionaryExamples: I don’t dispute that his films are entertaining.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nobody disputes nowadays the importance of learning another language and the advantages that this knowledge provides in adult life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to stop someone from being in a competition or doing some other activity because they have done something wrong
dictionaryExamples: She was disqualified from the race after a drugs test.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also a member wh[o] is not paying the contributions to the SOE club will be disqualified from it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when someone does not show respect or behave politely toward someone or something
dictionaryExamples: She apologized for not responding to the letter and said she had meant no disrespect.

sense.def: being rude and not showing any respect
dictionaryExamples: Don't be disrespectful to your mother.

sense.def: to interrupt something and stop it continuing as it should
dictionaryExamples: A heavy snowfall had disrupted the city's transportation system.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tea and coffee disrupt The Nerve System. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: when something is stopped from happening as it should

sense.def: causing problems that interrupt something and stop it continuing as it should
dictionaryExamples: disruptive behavior
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It can be very disruptive for families with children if one of the parents moves abroad for several months, maybe only coming home every other weekend or so. International English Language Testing System; C2; Dutch

sense.def: when someone is dissatisfied
dictionaryExamples:
At the moment she's experiencing a lot of dissatisfaction with
                         her job.

sense.def: not pleased or happy with something
dictionaryExamples: If you're dissatisfied with the service, why don't you complain to the hotel manager?

sense.def: a very long piece of writing done as part of a course of study
dictionaryExamples: She's writing a dissertation on American poetry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have completed my dissertation work on antifungal studies. International English Language Testing System; C1; Malayalam

sense.def: to end an organization or official arrangement
dictionaryExamples: Their marriage was dissolved in 1996.

sense.def: If a solid dissolves, it becomes part of a liquid, and if you dissolve it, you make it become part of a liquid.
dictionaryExamples: These tablets dissolve in water.

sense.def: the amount of space between two places
dictionaryExamples: What's the distance between Madrid and Barcelona/from Madrid to Barcelona?

Does she live withinwalking distance of her parents?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are also caves to explore a short distance away. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: somewhere that is far away, but close enough for you to see or hear the things that are there
dictionaryExamples: I could see Mary in the distance.

sense.def: far away
dictionaryExamples: a distant country

sense.def: not friendly
dictionaryExamples: She seemed cold and distant.

dictionaryExamples: a distant cousin

sense.def: different and separate
dictionaryExamples: This word has three distinct meanings.

dictionaryExamples: His great skill distinguishes him from the rest of the team.

dictionaryExamples: I couldn't distinguish anything in the darkness.

sense.def: famous, praised, or admired

dictionaryExamples: a ship in   distress

sense.def: extremely upset or worried

a distressing experience

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During the economic slowdown throughout the 1980s, the use of railroads for goods transport dropped significantly (about 50%) while terrestrial and water transport provided cheaper and mo[re] effective means of distribution. International English Language Testing System; C1; Spanish

sense.def: the way something is divided and shared in a group or area
dictionaryExamples: the distribution of wealth
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Poverty, domestic problems and [an] uneven distribution of wealth in the community make such children bitter and instead of working hard, they become reb[ell]ious and try to look for short cut[s] to gain money and comfort. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

the financial/business district
the Lake District/the Historic District

Mark dived off the bridge into the river.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know how to swim and dive from high places. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when you enter water headfirst with your arms held out above your head
dictionaryExamples: He entered the pool with a neat dive.

sense.def: when you spend some time swimming under water
dictionaryExamples: The center also offers night dives, which I highly recommend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It will start with a medical test, a few hours of theory, some training dives in a swimming pool and, at last, two dives on the reef. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: someone who swims under water, usually with breathing equipment
dictionaryExamples: a deep-sea diver
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've got [the qualification] of "open water diver''. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: varied or different
dictionaryExamples: Students from countries as diverse as Colombia and Lithuania use Cambridge textbooks.

dictionaryExamples: At the end of the lecture, I'd like all the students to divide into small discussion groups.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The class was divided in[to] two groups. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to calculate how many times a number can go into another number
dictionaryExamples: 12 divided by 6 equals 2.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is certainly clear to all that cars cannot continue to [enter the city] as they are currently doing, but this is a polemic subject and citizens are bound to be divided. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a difference or separation
dictionaryExamples: Because of debt repayments, the divide between rich and poor countries is continuing to grow.

sense.def: If a group, organization or country is divided, there are disagreements among the people in it.
dictionaryExamples: Board members are divided over the plans for the new stadium.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Opinions are divided. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the activity of swimming under water, usually with breathing equipment
dictionaryExamples: I want to go diving in Malta.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can go fishing, diving or windsurfing, it depends on how [you] would like to spend your time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian

sense.def: when something is separated into parts or groups, or the way that it is separated

sense.def: one of the groups in a business or organization
dictionaryExamples: the sales division
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being a lucky guy, I had the chance to work at the Disneyland Hotel, which is a division of the famous Walt Disney Company. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: one of the groups of teams in a league
dictionaryExamples: the Eastern Division
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At the moment I am twenty-one years old and I'm playing in the thir[d] division of the Belgian Soccer Association. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She felt a little bit dizzy. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who plays music on the radio or at live events
dictionaryExamples: He's a DJ on Radio 1.

sense.def: deoxyribonucleic acid; a chemical in the cells of living things which contains genetic information
dictionaryExamples: DNA evidence led to her arrest.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: All these things have a common root: the discovery of the structure of the DNA by Watson and Crick. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used with another verb to form questions and negative phrases
dictionaryExamples: Do you speak English?
Where do you work?
When does your train leave?
Why did you say that?
I don't know.
He doesn't eat meat.
I didn't see her there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What did you do at [the] party? Key English Test; A2; Italian

blocks.phrase: don't you?/do you?/doesn't she?/does she?, etc.

sense.def: used in a phrase at the end of a sentence to make the sentence a question
dictionaryExamples: You like her, don't you?
Sarah lives near here, doesn't she?
You didn't ask him, did you?
It doesn't hurt, does it?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You love watch[ing] tv, don't you?! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: something you say when politely asking if you can do something, or when asking someone else to do something
dictionaryExamples: Do you mind if  I turn on the television?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do you mind if I bring a friend? Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to be unsuccessful/successful
dictionaryExamples: Sam did very well in her exams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had done badly in my last exam and my teacher said she would talk to my mother. Preliminary English Test; B1; Tamil

sense.def: used to avoid repeating a verb that has just been used
dictionaryExamples: She runs much faster than he does.
Maria looks much healthier than she did.
"I hate that song!" "So do I."
"I don't like the heat." "Neither do I."
"May I join you?" "Please do!"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like Brad Pitt a lot, and so does she. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: used to give extra force to the main verb
dictionaryExamples: Do let me know if you need anything.
He does like you - he's just shy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I real[l]y do love to be a volunteer, to help people as much as I can. Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Romanian

sense.def: to perform an action
dictionaryExamples: What should we do?
What are you doing tonight?
Have you done your homework?
We did a lot of talking.
I've got nothing to do.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have nothing to do. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to perform a job in the house
dictionaryExamples: I do the cooking but Joe does most of the cleaning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She like[s] to do [the] cooking.  Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: used to ask what someone's job is
dictionaryExamples: "What do you do (for a living)?" "I'm a doctor."
What does Antonio do - does he teach?
I don't know what his wife does.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What does Angie do? Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to make or produce something
dictionaryExamples: I've done 20 copies of the handout.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [On] any sp[e]cial day [like] Devali they do some sp[e]cial sweet food. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Arabic

sense.def: used for talking or asking about someone and whether they are healthy, happy, or succeeding
dictionaryExamples: Hi, how are you doing?
"How is Freya doing?" "She's doing really well, thanks."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm doing fine. Preliminary English Test; B1; Estonian

sense.def: to perform a sports activity
dictionaryExamples: She does yoga in her spare time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [At the club,] I can swim, do karate [or] yoga, play soccer, tennis, squash and table-tennis. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to make your hair/makeup, etc. look nice
dictionaryExamples: It takes him half an hour to do his hair in the morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was the assistant of the person responsible for the clothes and make-up of the pop-group, [and] I was asked to do their make-up on my o[w]n. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to make the greatest effort possible
dictionaryExamples: I did my best to persuade him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll do my best to cover the work. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to have a good effect on someone
dictionaryExamples: A break from this would do us all good.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I must admit that my stay in your nice home did me good. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to cause damage/harm, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The fire did a lot of structural damage to the building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I promise not to do any damage! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be related to something
dictionaryExamples: She lacks confidence and I think that has to do with her childhood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that is nothing to do with my accident. Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Polish

sense.def: used to say that something seems like a good idea but it would be difficult to do
dictionaryExamples: I want to ask her out, but it's easier said than done.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know it's easier said than done but you have to try. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to try as hard as you can to do something
dictionaryExamples: We did our utmost to finish the project on time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, we l[i]ve in a materialistic society where we all do our utmost in order to make ends meet, but we are never satisfied. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: If something does the job, it achieves the desired result.
dictionaryExamples: I need somewhere to keep these papers – this folder should do the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Allow them to bring home friends and therefore develop social skills. In my opinion, that should do the job. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to use something that is less good than you would like
dictionaryExamples: If we can't get a bigger room we'll have to make do with this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Very calmly, he said "I am not going to put up with this. You might say that I am being too emotional, overreacting, whatever. But I will not come back until my piano has been returned.  And let me make very clear that I will not make do with another instrument." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If something does the trick, it solves a problem or has the result you want.
dictionaryExamples: If you have a headache, an aspirin will usually do the trick.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Using aromatherapy oil and scented candles always did the trick when she wanted to relax. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

blocks.phrasalVerb: do up sth or do sth up

sense.def: to repair or decorate a building so that it looks attractive
dictionaryExamples: He does up old houses and then sells them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think we could do up some of our old buildings that are nice but [which] the d[ir]t and the pollution  don't let us see. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to manage without having something
dictionaryExamples: Andrew's our best player - we can't really do without him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can't stand doing without the car. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to get rid of something or stop using something
dictionaryExamples: We may do away with the school uniform soon.
These ridiculous rules and regulations should have been done away with years ago.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Argentinians seem to be doing away with fried food and baking, boiling and steaming are now the most common ways of cooking. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: the place where ships stop and goods are taken off or put on
dictionaryExamples: We went to the dock to see the ship leave.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to take them with me to a very typical restaurant near the docks: Mummie's House 25 Harbour Street 2 Tel. 070 321 26 33. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: a person whose job is to treat people who are ill or hurt
dictionaryExamples: You should see a doctor about that cough.
Good morning, Doctor Smith/Doctor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to start on Saturday, because on Friday I have to go to the doctor with my grandmother. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: a piece of paper with official information on it
dictionaryExamples: official/confidential/legal documents
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My credit cards and official documents are inside. Key English Test; A2; Singhalese

sense.def: a piece of text produced electronically on a computer
dictionaryExamples: I'll send you the document by email.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That document was a "virus" and erased all my documents [o]n my computer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a film, television or radio program that gives facts and information about a subject
dictionaryExamples: The documentary took a fresh look at the life of Darwin.
They showed a documentary on animal communication.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's supposed to be a documentary about a man who lives with his wife and dogs in The Rockies, in Canada. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: an animal with fur, four legs and a tail, especially kept by people as a pet or to hunt or guard buildings
dictionaryExamples: my pet dog
wild dogs
dog food
We could hear dogs barking in the distance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She likes [going to the] park in her free time for a walk with her dog. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: a child's toy that looks like a small person or baby
dictionaryExamples: Lara loves playing with her dolls.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've got a cute doll. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the unit of money used in the US, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and some other countries
dictionaryExamples: Can I borrow ten dollars?
The suitcase was full of dollar bills.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Eugene gave me twenty dollars. Key English Test; A2; Malay

sense.def: an intelligent animal that lives in the sea, breathes air and looks like a large, smooth, gray fish
dictionaryExamples: They swam with dolphins on holiday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw a dolphin jumping in the air. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a particular area, activity, or subject that someone controls or deals with
dictionaryExamples: The garden is his domain.
This information should be in the public domain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also believe that robots will prevail in the domain of health, as they will take the place of doctors and surgeons. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: belonging or relating to the home, house or family
dictionaryExamples: domestic chores/duties/arrangements
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All domestic appliances such as showers, kettles, lights, TV and curtains may be voice activated. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: relating to a person's own country
dictionaryExamples: domestic airlines/flights
Domestic opinion had turned against the war.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We should advertise all [the] good points of our city in [the] domestic and foreign mass-media. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: power, influence, and control
dictionaryExamples: the company's dominance in the software industry
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The past taught us that progress and maturity are defined by leaving behind selfishness and extreme individualism, [the] need for control, and dominance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: main or most important
dictionaryExamples: Unemployment will be a dominant issue at the next election.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  Looking back on the ongoing discussion about women's role in modern German society, there is one dominant impression: women have to enlarge, improve, intensify, etc.... they have to enlarge their horizon, to improve their professional skills, to intensify their involvement in politics and so on ....Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: strongest and wanting to take control
dictionaryExamples: a dominant older brother
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was a very dominant boy and I was afraid of him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to have control over a place or a person
dictionaryExamples: He refuses to let others speak and dominates every meeting.
They work as a group - no one person is allowed to dominate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, in bank[s], school[s], hospital[s], [and] airport[s] we are absolutely dominated by computers, aren't we? First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to be the largest, most important, or most noticeable part of something
dictionaryExamples: The subject of pay dominated their discussions.
The cathedral dominates the skyline.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The religious values that dominated every aspect of life are slowly being replaced by new ones and the outcome of this metamorphosis has yet to be examined. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: great power and control over someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: world domination
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [A] more serious argument is that [the] domination of huge multinationals suppresses local creativity and forces the local traditions to fade away. International English Language Testing System; C1; Russian

sense.def: to give money or goods to help a person or organization
dictionaryExamples: An anonymous businesswoman donated one million dollars to the charity.
Please donate generously.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You don't have to pay for [it] but you can donate some money if you wish. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to allow some of your blood or part of your body to be used for medical purposes
dictionaryExamples: He donated a kidney to his sister.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, he once saved my life, putting his in danger by donating a large quantity of blood. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: when money or goods are given to help a person or organization
dictionaryExamples: donations of food and money
I'd like to make a small donation in my mother's name.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I would [like to] say that I and my friends are very happy because of Mr Maitland's donation. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: an animal like a small horse with long ears
dictionaryExamples: The donkey struggled with its heavy burden.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can use animals like donkeys for transportation. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: someone who gives some of their blood or part of their body to be used for medical purposes
dictionaryExamples: She is a regular blood donor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this group we can include responsible authorities, sympathetic doctors, organ donors, good teachers and many other unknown people who devote their lives to a generous cause. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who gives money or goods to a person or organization that needs help
dictionaryExamples: Ten thousand dollars was given by an anonymous donor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Private donors raised some funds to prevent the hospital from closure. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: death, destruction, and other unpleasant events that cannot be avoided
dictionaryExamples: a horrible sense of doom
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Men were not only humans but warriors who represented the army of immortals whose fate was to defend the Earth from the evil spirits of doom. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: unhappiness and feeling no hope for the future
dictionaryExamples: Life's not all doom and gloom, you know.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, experts can stop their doom and gloom statements about our uncertain future and the possible global crisis. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a flat object, often fixed at one edge, that is used to close the entrance of something such as a room or building, or the entrance itself
dictionaryExamples: the front door
the back door
a car door
a sliding door
The door to his bedroom was locked.
We could hear someone knocking at/on the door.
Could you open/close/shut the door, please?
She asked me to answer the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is a garden [outside the] back door but [it] isn't big. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Thai

sense.def: privately and not in public
dictionaryExamples: Most of the deals were made behind closed doors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Decisions which affect the whole world are made behind closed doors and are top secret. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: an entrance to a building or room through a door
dictionaryExamples: She waited in the doorway while I ran back inside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They sleep in doorways and beg in the street. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a measured amount of something such as medicine
dictionaryExamples: a high/low dose
a dose of medication/vaccine/radiation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is important to me because I have asthma and cannot miss even one dose of it. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: an amount of something, often something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: a dose of bad news
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You ought to plan your work and mainly learn in the morning when your brain is ready to accept a great dose of knowledge. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the spoken form of a period in an Internet or e-mail address, or some computer files
dictionaryExamples: "What's the web address?" "www dot cambridge dot org."

sense.def: a very small round mark
dictionaryExamples: The period at the end of this sentence is a dot.
Her skirt was blue with white dots.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the map we have marked a black dot on the place where you will find the hotel. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: at that exact time
dictionaryExamples: We have to leave at 7:30 on the dot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He gave him an address and told him to be there at six on the dot. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: twice the size, amount, price, etc., or consisting of two similar things together
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to book a double room.
I ordered a double espresso.
Go through the double doors and turn left.
The word "cool" has a double "o" in the middle.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to buy a double bed, that is why I need to sell the single one. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: twice as much or as many
dictionaryExamples: Our new house is double the size of the old one.
It'll cost you double that now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [There] has been an increase of 15% in the [number of] old people that live alone, and in the case of living in a care home, the percentage is double (50%) [that of] 1976. Skills for Life (Level 1); B2; Spanish

sense.def: to become twice the original size or amount, or to make something do this
dictionaryExamples: The government aims to double the number of students in higher education within 25 years.
Company profits have doubled since the introduction of new technology.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please repair it today and I will double your salary. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: when you are not certain about something, or do not trust someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I'm having doubts about his ability to do the job.
If there's any doubt about the rocket's engines, we ought to cancel the launch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have any doubt, send me an e-mail. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be certain
dictionaryExamples: I have no doubt (that) I made the right decision.
I never had any doubt (that) you would win.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maria went with me, and I have no doubt she loved the lake like I did. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: it is certain
dictionaryExamples: There is no doubt (that) he's a good player.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, there is no doubt that it is a nice one. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to not be certain
dictionaryExamples: The future of the project is in doubt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you don't know the difference, or if you are in doubt, keep on reading. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: certainly
dictionaryExamples: She is without doubt a great writer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Without a doubt we all are influenced by fashion in a number of ways. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: used to say that something is very likely
dictionaryExamples: No doubt she'll spend the money on new clothes.
