sense.def: to make people feel uncertain about someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Witnesses have cast doubt on the suspect's innocence.
A leading scientist has cast doubts on government claims that the medication is safe.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Wars lead to suffering, tears and [the] death of many people. They cast doubt on our humanity and values, especially in countries where the right to live is the princip[al] one. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: completely certain and without any doubt
dictionaryExamples: It is beyond doubt that she the best students I’ve ever taught.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What I would regard as being my most treasured possession is beyond doubt my precious collection of books. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

blocks.phrase: beyond a/the shadow of a doubt

sense.def: If something is true beyond a shadow of a doubt, it is certainly true.
dictionaryExamples: He convinced me , but it hasn't been proved beyond the shadow of a doubt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has been established beyond a shadow of a doubt that the growth in world population is one of the most compelling problems the Earth is facing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

blocks.phrase: give sb the benefit of the doubt

sense.def: to choose to believe what someone tells you even though it may be wrong or a lie
dictionaryExamples: She says her train was late, so I suppose we'd better give her the benefit of the doubt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every time our parents tell us ".. have you thought about it, are you sure you are not making a mistake?" we just answer "sure I have, no problem." Next time they do, let's give them the benefit of the doubt and let's think twice about the subject. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to feel uncertain about something or to think that something is not probable
dictionaryExamples: I doubt whether/if I can finish the work on time.
I doubt (that) I'll get the job.
He may come back tomorrow with the money, but I very much doubt it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She doubted if she could manage it at all. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to not believe someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Do you have any reason to doubt her?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After I had closed that window again, I doubted my senses. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: not probable
dictionaryExamples: It is doubtful whether/if he'll be able to come.
It was doubtful that the money would ever be found again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is certainly doubtful to say that the characteristics we are born with have much more influence on our personality than any experiences we may have in our life. International English Language Testing System; [no level]; Urdu

sense.def: not feeling certain about something
dictionaryExamples: The teacher is doubtful about having parents working as classroom assistants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very doubtful [about whether] you were there when it was held. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: moving from above and onto a surface
dictionaryExamples: Just as I was sitting down to watch TV, the phone rang.
Why don't you lie down on the sofa for a while?
This box is really heavy - can we put it down on the floor for a minute?
Get down off that table immediately, you silly girl!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So I sat down to write the answer. Preliminary English Test; B1; Latvian

sense.def: toward or in a low or lower position, from a higher one
dictionaryExamples: Is this elevator going down?
Don't look down! You'll get dizzy.
The sun's going down and it'll be dark soon.
I bent down to look under the bed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the mountains were colored when the sun was going down. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: in writing or on paper
dictionaryExamples: Do you have it down in writing/on paper, or was it just a verbal agreement?
I've put you down for three tickets each.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have to bring a pen and paper to write down the teacher's notes. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: used, especially with prepositions, to emphasize that a place is far from you or from somewhere considered to be central
dictionaryExamples: I'll meet you down at the gym after work.
He has a house down by the harbor.
I'm going down to the store to buy some milk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As soon as we drove down from the hills, I heard the noise from the town and I didn't like that. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: to be unhappy
dictionaryExamples: He looks a bit down in the dumps.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She felt happy when I was down in the dumps or in a fix and kept on being jealous of me concerning trivial matters. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in or toward a low or lower position, from a higher one
dictionaryExamples: I slid down the hill.
Aikiko fell down some stairs and broke her wrist.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was the first to go down the hill. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: along or further along
dictionaryExamples: We drove down the highway as far as Cape May.
Her office is down the hall on the right.
They sailed the boat down the river.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we went down the Nile by boat. Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: If money or work goes down the drain, it is wasted.
dictionaryExamples: If you leave the school now, all your hard work will go down the drain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All those evening conversations and the investment of 100,000 yen went down the drain, I thought. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: in the future
dictionaryExamples: Lots of things will have changed a few years down the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For that very reason it seemed natural for Laura and John to take her in, and further down the line they would adopt her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: unhappy or unable to feel excited or energetic about anything
dictionaryExamples: She's been really down since her husband died.
I've been (feeling) a bit down this week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are feeling down or depressed, what [do] you [do]? First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: If a computer or machine is down, it is temporarily not working.
dictionaryExamples: The network was down all morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If other departments use the online system, it seems to be down for a while. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: having no money, no luck and no opportunities
dictionaryExamples: Nobody loves you when you're down and out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The neglect of social security as a vital point in state policies leaves homeless people down and out, with little chance for improving their bleak prospects. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: toward the bottom of a hill or slope
dictionaryExamples: It's much easier to go downhill on a bike.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Skiing downhill in deep snow is the most rewarding experience. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to gradually become worse
dictionaryExamples: After his wife died, his health started to go downhill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had been going downhill in the last few days and so his death came as no surprise. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to copy computer programs, music or other information electronically, especially from the Internet or a larger computer
dictionaryExamples: I've downloaded the program.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I left [my computer] in your sister's room as she wanted to download some songs from it to her laptop. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: a computer program, music or other information that has been or can be downloaded
dictionaryExamples: a free download

sense.def: the disadvantage of a situation
dictionaryExamples: The downside of living in a city is all the pollution.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, there is a downside to it as more and more products are exported/imported, domestic economies lose a lot trying - and usually failing - to face the competition that is coming from other countries. International English Language Testing System; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to or on a lower floor of a building, especially the ground floor
dictionaryExamples: I ran downstairs to see who was at the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While I was in your house, your mom called me to help her carry some stuff, so I left my purse on your bed, and went downstairs to help her. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: on or at a lower floor of a building, especially the ground floor
dictionaryExamples: The burglars got in through a downstairs window.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every year when winter com[es], our heating [doe]sn't work very well. [The] upstairs rooms [are] ok, but [the] downstairs rooms are cold. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Polish

sense.def: Down-to-earth people or ideas are practical and work well.
dictionaryExamples: I like your down-to-earth approach to problem-solving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His huge popularity mainly lies in his down-to-earth attitude. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to the central part or main business area of a city
dictionaryExamples: If we go downtown we can take the bus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday I went downtown to buy some clothes. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: in or at the central part or main business area of a city
dictionaryExamples: downtown Chicago
Our office is in the downtown business district.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will be waiting for you at the new downtown restaurant, don't forget that! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: moving toward a lower position
dictionaryExamples: a downward trend
The country's economy is on a downward spiral.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Company B's profit marks a downward tendency from 1990 to 2000, going from [a] 2 million dollar profit to the extrem[e] result of no profit at all. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: a situation which is getting worse very quickly, and which is difficult to control
dictionaryExamples: After his death, the family went into a downward spiral.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unemployment is one of the major problems of our society. It is the first step of a downward spiral. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: toward a lower place or level
dictionaryExamples: The road slopes downward to the river.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Water runs downward into [the] turbine when the valve is open. International English Language Testing System; C1; Telugu

sense.def: twelve
dictionaryExamples: a dozen eggs
This recipe makes three dozen cookies.
Could you get me half a dozen eggs when you go to the store?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were a dozen people. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a lot
dictionaryExamples: She's got dozens of friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are, as well, dozens of robots able to handle any kind of work in our homes. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a title for someone who is a medical doctor or a Doctor of Philosophy
dictionaryExamples: I have an appointment with Dr. Tay.
Dr. Woolley has retired.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dr. Ahuja has placed a virus in a suitcase. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a piece of writing or a plan that is not yet in its finished form
dictionaryExamples: This is only a rough draft - the finished article will have pictures as well.
She asked me to check the first draft of her proposal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I can use my computer for making monthly reports at home [and] making different kinds of project drafts. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a current of cold air in a room
dictionaryExamples: I felt a cold draft every time the door opened.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, there is a draft in the [house], [be]cause wind is [blow]ing around the house, which makes us feel cold, wh[ich] is harmful for my child especially. International English Language Testing System; C1; Russian

sense.def: to produce a piece of writing or a plan that you intend to change later
dictionaryExamples: to draft a letter
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My job is to present an advertising material draft that will be edited by our customer's representative. International English Language Testing System; C1; Kazakh

sense.def: to move something on a computer screen using a mouse
dictionaryExamples: Drag the highlighted text to the new window.

sense.def: to move something on  a computer screen using a mouse and place it where you want it to be
dictionaryExamples: drag and drop exercises

sense.def: to pull someone or something along the ground, usually with difficulty
dictionaryExamples: Pick the chair up instead of dragging it behind you!
She dragged the canoe down to the water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another man approached the agent, both watching as officers dragged the man to a nearby car. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: to make someone go somewhere they do not want to go
dictionaryExamples: She dragged me along to look at shoes with her.
I have to drag myself out of bed every morning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When she first saw him, speaking his radical views at some sort of political meeting she had been dragged along to by a friend, she was at first scared but later enchanted. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to continue for too much time in a boring way
dictionaryExamples: The play dragged during the second act.
Negotiations dragged on for months.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The afternoon dragged on interminably, and I suddenly felt like going out. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to remove the liquid from something, usually by pouring it away or allowing it to flow away
dictionaryExamples: Drain the pasta and add the sauce.
We drained the pond and filled it with fresh water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Peter the Great ordered the swampy lands to be drained. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: If something drains, liquid flows away or out of it.
dictionaryExamples: Don't bother drying the pans - just leave them to drain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sink doesn't drain, which is a major problem for me. International English Language Testing System; C2; Turkish

sense.def: to reduce or cause something to reduce
dictionaryExamples: The long war had drained the resources of both countries.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These people drain government funds that can be used to deal with unemployment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to make someone very tired
dictionaryExamples: The long journey drained him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Especially when you've had a hard day at work, when the constant high temperature drains the energy from you, or when you're not feeling well because of any other reason, you need that comforting phone call from your best friend more than ever. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a pipe or hole that takes away waste liquids or water
dictionaryExamples: She poured the dirty water down the drain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wish to put forward some ideas, which I think can help:   checking the area and surroundings, making sure there is no garbage lying around; cleaning the fallen leaves etc. from the drains. International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: something that uses a lot of money or energy
dictionaryExamples: Taking care of his sick mother was quite a drain on him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This need results in an ever increasing drain on [the] country's resources. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If money or work goes down the drain, it is wasted.
dictionaryExamples: If you leave the school now, all your hard work will go down the drain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All those evening conversations and the investment of 100,000 yen went down the drain, I thought. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: a play in a theater or on television or radio, or plays and acting generally
dictionaryExamples: She's been in several television dramas.
He's the drama critic for the Times.
She studied English and drama in college.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a drama club. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: an event or situation, especially an unexpected one, in which there is worry or excitement and usually a lot of action
dictionaryExamples: We had a little drama last night when the oil in the pan caught fire.
There was a lot of drama in the courtroom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fortunately he found [my ring]. How happy I was! The drama was over! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: very sudden or noticeable, or full of action and excitement
dictionaryExamples: a dramatic change/improvement
We watched scenes of the dramatic rescue on the news.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His suicide at the end of the book was the most dramatic event in this story and has touched me deeply. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: suddenly or obviously
dictionaryExamples: Your life changes dramatically when you have a baby.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She fell dramatically to the floor. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: severe and sudden or having very noticeable effects
dictionaryExamples: drastic measures
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If within 30 days I don't receive any kind of compensation (preferably money), I may have to take drastic measures. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: in a drastic way
dictionaryExamples: The number of bees has drastically declined due to a combination of factors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Conditions have changed drastically after the reunification. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to make a picture of something or someone with a pencil or pen
dictionaryExamples: Jonathan can draw beautifully.
The children drew pictures of their families.
Draw a line at the bottom of the page.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You have to bring pencils and sheets of paper to draw on. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to move in a particular direction, especially in a vehicle
dictionaryExamples: The train slowly drew into the station/drew in.
As we drew alongside the black car, I suddenly recognized my ex-boyfriend at the wheel.
Montgomery drew level with Greene in the 100 meters final, but never passed him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I drew up at the gate of the house; the inside was in darkness and nobody seemed to be there. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to attract someone to a place or person
dictionaryExamples: He's an excellent speaker who always draws a crowd.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, I am sure that opening a swimming pool again would help to draw people living in the nearest villages to our town. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to make someone notice something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Could I draw your attention to item number three on the agenda?
Does he wear those ridiculous clothes to draw attention to himself?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you very much for drawing attention to this letter. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to consider the facts of a situation and make a decision about what is true, correct, likely to happen, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I'd seen them together so often I drew the logical conclusion that they were husband and wife.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since nobody ever heard from them again, we all drew the sad conclusion that they must be dead. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to become nearer in space or time
dictionaryExamples: Her birthday's drawing nearer every day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After two seconds he heard a door opening and his mother drawing near. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to pull something or someone gently in a particular direction
dictionaryExamples: He took her hand and drew her toward her sister.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As she drew me into the house she would tell me a story about Dari's absence and [the] newly born puppies of Dari's, almost whispering into my ears as my eyes welled up with tears. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to be almost finished
dictionaryExamples: At last the concert drew to a close.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the dinner drew to an end, our weariness became all too clear. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to say that there is a similarity or difference between two things
dictionaryExamples: We need to draw a distinction between criticism and insults.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A country sh[ould] not be visited only to enable the tourist to draw a comparison between his country and the foreign one. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: If someone says they know where to draw the line, they are talking about knowing at what point an activity or situation becomes unacceptable because it is wrong or too extreme
dictionaryExamples: I’ll do what I can to help a friend, but I draw the line when someone asks me to lie for them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For these parents, drawing the line at certain behaviors became a s[y]nonym for lack of democracy, and a source of struggle at home. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to use information or your knowledge or experience of something to help you do something
dictionaryExamples: His novels draw heavily on his childhood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This report looks at the changes in eating habits in Italy, drawing on personal experience, magazine and newspaper articles and interviews with local people of different ages. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

blocks.phrasalVerb: draw sth up or draw up sth

sense.def: to prepare something, usually a plan, list, or an official agreement, by writing it
dictionaryExamples: She drew up a list of contestants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Government bodies have drawn up plans to educate people and explain to them why it is so important to keep our planet safe and clean. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: a problem or disadvantage
dictionaryExamples: The only drawback to this camera is its price.
One of the main drawbacks of using this program is the amount of memory it uses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Both perspectives are important, but, overall, the advantages of proper in-house teaching outweigh the drawbacks. International English Language Testing System; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a box-shaped container without a top which is part of a piece of furniture. It slides in and out to open and close and is used for keeping things in.
dictionaryExamples: I keep my socks in the bottom drawer.
I don't like to go through other people's drawers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I left it in your drawer in the living room. Key English Test; A2; Slovak

sense.def: the act of making a picture with a pencil or pen, or a picture made in this way
dictionaryExamples: Rosie loves drawing.
She gave me a beautiful drawing of a horse.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobbies are singing, dancing, drawing, writing, reading and so on. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to feel worried or frightened about something that has not happened yet
dictionaryExamples: I'm dreading the first day at my new school.
I dread running into them again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You could go through life regretting the past and dreading the future, and become a grump[y] old man, or you could take it all as it comes, and enjoy every single moment. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: extremely bad or unpleasant
dictionaryExamples: The food was bad and the service was dreadful.
I was beginning to think I'd made a dreadful mistake.
The news report was so dreadful that I just had to switch it off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What a dreadful nightmare! First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a series of events or images that happen in your mind when you are sleeping
dictionaryExamples: a bad dream
I had a very odd dream about you last night.
Paul had a dream that he won the lottery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought it was a very strange dream but her dream wasn't strange it was nice. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: something that you want to happen very much but that is not very likely
dictionaryExamples: It's always been my dream to take flying lessons.
Winning all that money was a dream come true.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My dream was to become a professional singer. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to not notice things that are around you because you are thinking about something else
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first time I [saw a fashion]  show, I was 10 years old and I [was] in a dream during the [whole] show. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: bigger or better than anything you could imagine or hope for
dictionaryExamples: The house was beyond my wildest dreams.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [It] was beyond my wildest dreams. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that something is better than anything you could imagine or hope for
dictionaryExamples: Never in my wildest dreams had I thought I would be offered a starring role in a Hollywood movie.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not even in my wildest dreams could I have imagined that finding a diary was to have such fortunate consequences for me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to experience events and images in your mind while you are sleeping
dictionaryExamples: What did you dream about last night?
I often dream about/of flying.
I dreamed that I was having a baby.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It ran, ran, and I screamed - I was dreaming, but it was very real. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to imagine something that you would like to happen
dictionaryExamples: He never dreamed that one day he would become President.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have always dreamed [of] becom[ing] a famous tennis [player]. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to say that you would not do something because you think it is wrong or silly
dictionaryExamples: I wouldn't dream of asking him for a loan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many people wouldn't dream of spending hours in a kitchen preparing a complex meal. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a piece of clothing for women or girls which covers the top half of the body and hangs down over the legs
dictionaryExamples: a long/short dress
a wedding dress
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wore a new dress. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: to put clothes on yourself or someone else, especially a child
dictionaryExamples: My husband dresses the children while I make breakfast.
He left very early and had to dress in the dark.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maria started to dress, but her suit was not there! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to wear a particular type of clothes
dictionaryExamples: I have to dress nicely for work.
Patricia always dresses in black.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The waiters dress in national clothes and are very kind. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: wearing clothes and not naked
dictionaryExamples: I usually get dressed before I eat breakfast.
He was dressed in a dark gray suit.
They arrived early and I wasn't fully dressed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While I got dressed he started to cook the dinner. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: wearing clothing of a particular type
dictionaryExamples: a well-dressed/casually dressed man
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last Saturday, there was a big party and everyone w[as] well dressed. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a piece of furniture with drawers for keeping clothes in
dictionaryExamples: I keep my socks in the top drawer of the dresser.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I have left my notebook in your house. It's probably in your bedroom on the dresser. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a liquid or an amount of liquid which is taken into the body through the mouth
dictionaryExamples: Would you like a drink of water/tea/juice?
They'd had no food or drink for two days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to have [a] drink. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: alcoholic liquid
dictionaryExamples: Whose turn is it to buy the drinks?
One drink is my limit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After the film we go and have a drink. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: a strong alcoholic drink
dictionaryExamples: I thought he could use a stiff drink after that car almost hit him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, she prepared herself a stiff drink: gin and tonic with some ice, the very same one she used to have when Jack was there. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to take liquid into the body through the mouth
dictionaryExamples: He drank three glasses of water.
The animals came down to the water hole to drink.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You do not have to bring any food, but I['d be] pleased if you could bring something to drink: wine, coke or something. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Hungarian

sense.def: to drink alcohol
dictionaryExamples: "Would you like a glass of wine?" "No thanks, I don't drink."
I didn't drink at all while I was pregnant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Did you drink or dance at the party? Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to move or travel on land in a motor vehicle, especially as the person controlling the vehicle's movement
dictionaryExamples: I'm learning to drive.
"Are you going by train?" "No, I'm driving."
She drives a red sports car.
They're driving to Nashville on Tuesday.
We saw their car outside the house and drove past/away.
I drove my daughter to school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I need them to drive my car. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: to make someone extremely annoyed
dictionaryExamples: My mother-in-law has been staying with us this past week and she's driving me crazy.
He leaves dirty clothes all over the floor and it's driving me nuts.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It drove me crazy. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

blocks.phrase: drive sb to sth; drive sb to do sth

sense.def: to make someone have a bad feeling or do something bad
dictionaryExamples: The arguments drove her to leave home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She would discover all about her affair with Lorraine's husband and the real cause that drove him to commit suicide. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to provide the power or energy that makes someone or something work
dictionaryExamples: She was driven by greed and ambition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, we are reassured by large international corporations that everything is under control, but it is common knowledge that these capitalistic monsters are [so] driven by greed for money and power that they would say anything to calm down the public. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to force someone or something to leave a place
dictionaryExamples: The supermarket has driven many small shops out of the area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately that kind of thinking led to many people being killed, wounded and made homeless and moreover driven out of their homeland. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: a journey in a car
dictionaryExamples: The drive from Boston to New York took four hours.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This restaurant is about [a] 1 hour drive from my home. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hindi

sense.def: a part of a computer that can read or store information
dictionaryExamples: Save your work on the C drive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then we learned how to install components like a Soundboard or a CD-Rom drive. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: energy and determination to achieve things
dictionaryExamples: She has drive and ambition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They definitely have the drive and motivation to succeed. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: someone who drives a vehicle
dictionaryExamples: a bus/truck/taxi driver
The driver of the van was killed in the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you don't know the place exactly ask the driver. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: official permission for someone to drive a car, received after passing a driving test, or a document showing this
dictionaryExamples: I have a clean driving licence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first we were scared that we won't be allowed to come in the club cause the club is aged by 18 years and normal[l]y you had to show your driver's license. Primary English Test; [no level]; Albanian

sense.def: to fall or to allow something to fall
dictionaryExamples: She dropped her keys.
I'm always dropping things.
Amanda dropped her sunglasses in/into the fountain.
The book dropped from/off the shelf.
Don't drop it!/Don't let it drop!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe this is the reason why I dropped my cup of tea. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to move something on  a computer screen using a mouse and place it where you want it to be
dictionaryExamples: drag and drop exercises
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With simple mouse-clicks and by means of the well-known "drag-and-drop" method, this programme will enable you to select a fabric from the catalogue and "drop" it on a chair or couch, to see what they look like. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to move to a lower level, or cause something to move to a lower level
dictionaryExamples: The water level in the flooded region has finally begun to drop.
The land drops (away) sharply behind the house.
We've had to drop our prices because of the recession.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Especially if you imagine that the number of heart-attacks was about 40% per year and for [the] last 3 years dropped down to 23%. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to stop doing or planning something, especially an activity
dictionaryExamples: I'm going to drop yoga and do aerobics instead.
Can you drop what you're doing and help me with this report?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think you shouldn't drop sports but on the other hand, if you drop sports and do music, it [would be] quite good as well. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to take someone or something to a place, usually by car as you travel somewhere else
dictionaryExamples: I can drop you at the station on my way to work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You [had] better hire a car or get to know somebody who can drop you there. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to stop talking about something, especially because it is annoying or upsetting someone
dictionaryExamples: I don't want to talk about it any more - let's drop the subject.

sense.def: to die very suddenly
dictionaryExamples: He just dropped dead.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can enjoy our longer lives because we don't have to work until we drop dead. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a small round-shaped amount of liquid
dictionaryExamples: I thought I felt a drop of rain.
There were little drops of paint on the kitchen floor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could only hear the drops against the window-pane. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a reduction in the amount or level of something
dictionaryExamples: a drop in crime
The recent drop in magazine subscriptions is causing some concern.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It maintain[ed] the same level between 1998 and 2008 after a drop from 1996 to 1998.  International English Language Testing System; B2; Korean

sense.def: a vertical distance down from somewhere to the ground
dictionaryExamples: It's a drop of about 50 feet from the top of the cliff.

sense.def: a very small amount compared to the amount needed
dictionaryExamples: My letter of protest was just a drop in the ocean.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know I am a drop in the ocean, but I'm convinced it's the only way, my way, of contributing to improve education in Mexico. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a long period when there is no rain and people do not have enough water
dictionaryExamples: A severe drought ruined the crops.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have wars, revolutions, political unrest, famine, drought, pollution, etc. Some of our problems are difficult to solve. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to die because you are under water and cannot breathe, or to kill someone in this way
dictionaryExamples: Two people drowned in a boating accident yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those days we spent in Brazil were full of excit[e]ment and I certainly wouldn't mind doing it again - well, except [for] the episode in which you almost drowned when we went water-skiing. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: If a loud noise drowns the sound of something else, it prevents that sound from being heard.
dictionaryExamples: His voice was drowned out by the traffic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is furthermore impossible to listen to music as it is drowned by the noise. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: any natural or artificially made chemical which is used as a medicine
dictionaryExamples: anti-cancer/fertility/pain-killing drugs
a prescription/over-the-counter drug
He takes several drugs for his condition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A great many drug companies all over the world have reduced input of dangerous chemicals into rivers, lakes and seas. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: any natural or artificially made chemical which is taken for pleasure, to improve someone's performance of an activity, or because a person cannot stop using it
dictionaryExamples: illegal drugs
a drug addict
drug addiction/abuse
She began to suspect that her son was on/taking/doing drugs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, I have never taken drugs. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a store where you can buy medicines, other health products, make-up and products used for washing yourself
dictionaryExamples: I can pick up the shampoo while I'm at the drugstore.
Since most drugstores close at 10 p.m, you must wait until [the] next morning. (765596; First Certificate in English; Russia; B2 VANTAGE; 2001; Russian; Pass)

sense.def: a round, hollow musical instrument that you hit with your hand or a stick
dictionaryExamples: a bass/snare/kettle drum
a drum beat
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am a very good drummer because I have played the drums for six years. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: unable to behave or speak normally because of having had too much alcohol
dictionaryExamples: He got very drunk at my sister's wedding.
I'd had a glass of wine but I certainly wasn't drunk.
He came home last night blind drunk.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, I just sat down watching Julie and her monstrous friends drinking and acting like animals - they were all blind drunk! First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: describes something that has no water or other liquid in, on, or around it
dictionaryExamples: My hat kept my hair dry.
These plants grow well in a dry climate.
This cake's a bit dry - I think I overcooked it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So when the clothes were dry, I called a taxi. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: with no or not much rain
dictionaryExamples: a dry summer
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It said: "My sweet darling, the weather here in Africa is hot and dry, but the nights are cold and lonely without you." Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: Dry wine is not sweet.
dictionaryExamples: I'd like a glass of dry white wine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The only wine sold - a dry white wine of a very good quality - is the one made by the owners of the restaurant and I can assure you that it's worth trying it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: Dry skin or hair does not feel soft or smooth.
dictionaryExamples: My lips feel really dry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She looked old, her skin was dry and her eyes so lucid... . Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: If a book, talk, or subject is dry, it is not interesting.
dictionaryExamples: His writing is always so dry and dull.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Facts and dates are dry and empty if teachers are not able to bring them to life. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to become dry, or to make something become dry
dictionaryExamples: Will this paint dry by tomorrow?
Hang the clothes up to dry.
The fruit is dried in the sun.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I invited him to come inside and dry his clothes and have a cup of tea. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: If a supply of something dries up, it ends.
dictionaryExamples: The work dried up and he went out of business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless we must consider that a society with many [people] over sixty has its problems, such as retirement funds which [have] dried up. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: having two parts, or having two of something
dictionaryExamples: dual nationality
She's got a bit of a dual personality.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have dual nationality. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: thought not to be completely true, honest, or legal
dictionaryExamples: dubious evidence
a man with a dubious reputation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was blackmailed, his children were twice kidnapped and his wife was badly injured in mysterious and dubious circumstances. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: not certain that something is good or true
dictionaryExamples: He's dubious about the benefits of acupuncture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As far as entertainers are concerned, I am rather dubious about their contribution to a better world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a bird that lives by water, has webbed feet, a short neck and a large beak
dictionaryExamples: We took some bread to feed the ducks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was a big lake, with a lot of ducks. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

blocks.phrase: be (like) water off a duck's back

sense.def: If criticisms, insults, etc. are like water off a duck's back to you, they do not affect you at all.
dictionaryExamples: She calls him lazy and useless, but it's like water off a duck's back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main lesson I have learned is by looking at some people who have lived alone for most of their life and faced with neither contradiction nor argument, they stay in their ivory tower, so sure of their opinions that whatever you say is like water off a duck's back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: expected to happen, arrive, etc. at a particular time
dictionaryExamples: What time is the next bus due?
The next meeting is due to be held in three months' time.
Their first baby is due in January.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is my science assignment which is due on Tuesday, so I have no time to research and write it again. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: because of
dictionaryExamples: A lot of her unhappiness is due to boredom.
Due to wet leaves on the line, this train will arrive an hour late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I want to say that France is the best place to cycle, due to its mountains and fantastic forests. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: at a suitable time in the future
dictionaryExamples: The results will be sent to you in due course.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I look forward to hearing from you in due course. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: If you are due for something, it should happen very soon.
dictionaryExamples: I'm due for a check-up at the dentist's.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The facilities and canteen are due for improvement too. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: used to politely disagree with or give a negative opinion about something
dictionaryExamples: I’ve been thinking about what you said and, with all due respect, I think you’re mistaken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally we would like to point out two [things] that should be improved. The first one is entertainment, which, with all due respect, is very poor. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: Something that is due to you is something that is owed to you or something you deserve.
dictionaryExamples: He didn't get the praise and recognition that was due to him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Slowly she walked into the living room, knowing that a big apology was due [to her]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: correct and suitable
dictionaryExamples: He was fined for driving without due care and attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, we should take due care not to make wrong assumptions and be prejudicial to others as a consequence. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: not interesting or exciting in any way; boring
dictionaryExamples: She wrote dull, respectable articles for the local newspaper.
He's pleasant enough, but deadly dull.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion the film was very boring because the story was poor and dull. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: not bright
dictionaryExamples: dull colors
dull weather
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The color of our house from an outside view is dull yellow, and every time I look at it, it reminds me of the past so I would have it painted something brighter so that I would not fee[l] bad. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: stupid
dictionaryExamples: a dumb idea/question
I feel so dumb - I should have know that's what you meant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please forgive me, I can be so dumb sometimes! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: physically unable to talk
dictionaryExamples: The child is deaf and dumb.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first one is "Lessons of Piano". It is the story of a dumb woman who uses a piano to express her feelings and moods. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: to put something somewhere to get rid of it, especially in a place where you should not put it
dictionaryExamples: The company was fined for illegally dumping toxic chemicals.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: In addition, society might be affected negatively by the refuse and garbage dumped by people. 
 International English Language Testing System; C1; Ibo/Igbo

sense.def: to put something somewhere quickly and carelessly
dictionaryExamples: Henry dumped his bag on the table and went upstairs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Annabel dumped her school bag on the floor and threw herself onto her bed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to suddenly end a romantic relationship
dictionaryExamples: If he's so awful, why don't you just dump him?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had just been dumped by a guy I thought I was in love with. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: a place where people take things that they do not want
dictionaryExamples: We took our old mattress to the dump.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We all took turns loading it and driving it off to the city dump, in our private cars. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a place that is dirty and messy
dictionaryExamples: His room is a dump.

sense.def: to be unhappy
dictionaryExamples: He looks a bit down in the dumps.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She felt happy when I was down in the dumps or in a fix and kept on being jealous of me concerning trivial matters. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the amount of time that something lasts
dictionaryExamples: The singer remained in the hotel for the duration of his stay in the UK.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are between 18 and 30 years old, we offer you a wide range of jobs with a duration varying from two weeks to three months. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: for the whole of a period of time
dictionaryExamples: They work during the night and sleep during the day.
There were huge advances in aviation technology during World War II
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We sat together during the lesson. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: at some time between the beginning and the end of a period
dictionaryExamples: I woke up several times during the night.
The program will be shown on television during the weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last year, the strangest thing happened to me during [the] Christmas period. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: dry dirt in the form of powder that covers surfaces inside a building, or very small dry pieces of soil, sand or other substances
dictionaryExamples: The furniture was covered in dust.
A cloud of dust rose in the air as the car roared past.
coal dust
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also, in the countryside there are more bugs and dust than in the city. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: covered with dust
dictionaryExamples: a dusty old chair
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not a sound could be heard in the dusty street except for the contin[u]ous roar of my almost useless pick-up. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: something that you have to do because it is part of your job, or something that you feel is the right thing to do
dictionaryExamples: I felt it was my duty to tell them the truth.
He only went to see her out of a sense of duty.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is not enjoyable if you look at it as a duty. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: something you do as part of your job or because of your position
dictionaryExamples: professional/official duties
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And it is the most important duty of the local police to keep an eye on hooligans. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: If someone such as a doctor or a soldier is on duty, they are working, and if they are off duty, they are not working.
dictionaryExamples: What time are you off/on duty tomorrow?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was on duty in front of the major's house with another soldier. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: Duty-free goods are things you can buy and bring into a country without paying tax.
dictionaryExamples: I bought some duty-free perfume at the airport.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We went to get some alcohol in a duty-free shop. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: digital versatile disc or digital video disc: a disc used for storing and playing music, films or information
dictionaryExamples: I've got a DVD of the first series.
Is the movie available on DVD?
a DVD player
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: ALL our friends w[ere] there and I got a new DVD! Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: full of ideas, energy and enthusiasm
dictionaryExamples: She's young and dynamic and will be a great addition to the team.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am a cheerful, dynamic and hardworking person. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: continuously changing or moving
dictionaryExamples: a dynamic economy
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Consequently, the country has a less dynamic economy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch
